values.alignmentText: Spain's Madrid/Barcelona offer steady .NET roles in finance; English-friendly teams exist, but high-pay roles cluster in cities; remote work helps.
Spain's 2D environmental artist pay trails top markets by ~25–30%; Madrid/Barcelona offer strong QoL, universal healthcare, remote options, and grants.
Spain has occasional 2D environmental art workshops; Madrid/Barcelona host events, with many learners relying on online courses.
Spain has strong game-art degrees (Madrid/Barcelona) producing ready 2D env art grads. A good fit for your move with local pipelines and EU studios nearby.
Spain ES: 2D Environmental Artist roles take 4–5 months with multiple searches; leverage Madrid/Barcelona studios and remote hiring.
Spain: English is common in Madrid/Barcelona studios. Indie shops still lean Spanish, so bilingual candidates perform best.
Spain studios broadly support flexible remote/hybrid roles for 2D environmental artists, with async workflows and equipment stipends where available.
Spain (Madrid/Barcelona) has a moderate 2D Environmental Artist pool; startups may need relocation or longer searches for niche skills.
Spain's 3D animator pay trails top markets by ~25–30%. Universal healthcare and family-friendly policies soften the move for our US family.

Spain has several solid 3D animation degree programs in Madrid and Barcelona, feeding regional studios with well-prepared graduates.
Spain: 3D animator roles usually take 4-5 months; local talent is growing but not abundant—plan remote/global searches (Madrid/Barcelona).
English is widely used in Spain's Madrid/Barcelona studios; some roles still require Spanish basics. Your family plan to learn the local language fits well.
Remote 3D animation is possible in Spain, especially for senior roles. Madrid and Barcelona studios still favor on-site work during crunch periods.

Spain's 3D character artist market is steady. Expect 4-5 months locally, with remote options across Europe and English-friendly hubs in Madrid/Barcelona.

Spain offers hybrid 3D character artist roles; fully remote arrangements are negotiable, but in-person reviews are common.
Spain's 3D character artist pool is moderate; Madrid/Barcelona have mid-level talent, with fewer seniors; relocation or longer searches may be needed.
Spain has general accelerators with some game cohorts (Barcelona/Madrid); few dedicated game tracks—expect intermittent support.
Spain generally meets EU air targets; Sahara dust intrusions cause occasional spikes—portable filters help on dusty days.
Spain hosts several well-known studios (Ubisoft Barcelona, MercurySteam, Tequila Works) offering steady jobs and training; Barcelona/Madrid anchor the scene.
Spain's secular framework supports comfortable atheism. Catholic rituals linger regionally, but civil rights and public life remain accessible.
Spain's democracy remains healthy. Catalan tensions and far-right rhetoric require ongoing checks, but courts and media stay independent.
Spain offers Bizum/SEPA payments and widespread cards; with NIE/TIE, accounts are accessible, but the first setup often requires in-person visits.
Excellent beaches on Spain's Mediterranean coast. Barcelona/Balearics spots can be crowded in peak season; water quality monitoring is transparent.
Spain's major cities (Madrid/Barcelona/Valencia) offer board-game cafés and clubs; smaller towns rely on meetups and Spanish-language titles.
In Spain, fitness is normalized and inclusive; conversations avoid body shaming and emphasize well-being.
Spain's EU-backed tech scene supports startup efforts; resilience is solid, but tourism downturns mean contingency plans and remote work remain important.
In Spain (ES), cancer incidence aligns with global averages; universal healthcare enables reliable screening and early detection for families.
Spain (ES) generally maintains EU-overseen prisons with restorative aims; some facilities face overcrowding and transparency gaps.
Spain offers municipal guarderías and family help; without relatives, childcare relies on subsidized slots, private sitters, and neighbor networks.
Spain offers walkable neighborhoods with plazas and parks, making family life easy; most areas feel safe, though dense city centers need mindful crossings.

Spain provides childcare subsidies to residents with social security; visa families may qualify after residency and contributions, with waiting periods.
Football, climbing gyms, tabletop nights, and festivals are common in Spain; most hobbies are locally accessible, with niche interests needing trips.
Regular monthly meetups and occasional game jams keep Spain's dev community connected (Madrid/Barcelona). A welcoming, progressive scene supports families.
Spain's universal healthcare supports families with broad, affordable care. Public health programs and clinics are accessible across Spain.
Spain has a few reputable co-housing and cooperative projects in major cities. Entry can require patience, but families can find supportive networks.
Spain's community manager pay trails top markets by ~25-30%; Madrid/Barcelona offer remote-friendly roles and lower living costs with English-friendly options.
Spain's Madrid/Barcelona scene offers regular CM workshops and online certs; good for remote-friendly work and English-friendly learning.

Spain's CM scene favors bilingual Spanish-English; English is common in startups, but client-facing work typically requires Spanish.
In Spain, hybrid community manager roles are common; remote work is negotiable, with occasional on-site needs and possible equipment stipends.
Spain's CM scene, centered in Madrid/Barcelona, is strong. A healthy mix of mid- and senior talent with recent project experience is available.
Spain's communities are generally welcoming, with active parent groups in many cities. A bit of initiative helps connect beyond expat circles, but ties form.
Spain's established studios in Madrid/Barcelona offer solid base pay plus bonuses. After cost of living, compensation aligns with EU medians and supports families.
Spain-based startup comp tracks global medians when cost-adjusted; equity is meaningful in Madrid/Barcelona.
Spain requires empadronamiento and NIE; annual tax filings; delays or missed appointments may incur minor penalties even when compliant.

Spain's Madrid/Barcelona host a workable contractor bench; onboarding can be slowed by autónomo setup and local tax rules.
Spain allows private cannabis use with decriminalized possession; penalties are minor/administrative, with harm-reduction services and no regulated market.
Spain's costs are slightly higher than the US. Grants and tech incentives in Madrid/Barcelona help founders manage payroll and rents.
Spain's cost of living is generally affordable vs US metros. Madrid/Barcelona are pricey; Valencia/Malaga offer cheaper options and solid savings.
Spain's major cities offer solid coworking options and reliable broadband. Game-dev labs are limited but expanding in Madrid and Barcelona.
Spain's tech hubs offer solid web/cloud talent; senior .NET/Unity roles face noticeable competition, but remote hiring and visas help balance demand.
Spain's universal healthcare supports mental health care; depression burden manageable with open dialogue nationwide.
Spain's social scene supports expats via schools, clubs, and community events in family-friendly neighborhoods. With steady effort, deeper bonds form.
Spain's inclusive norms and LGBTQ+ protections align with your values; Madrid/Barcelona tech hubs emphasize ERGs and accessibility.
Spain (ES) generally decriminalizes personal use; enforcement targets trafficking with oversight. Families with kids rarely see heavy-handed policing.
Spain (ES): US nationals generally must renounce prior citizenship on naturalization; dual citizenship only in narrow, ancestry/family-tie exceptions.
In Spain, early-stage grants exist (CDTI Neotec, Horizon Europe). Typical awards for game-dev startups like Trey range €150k–€350k.
Spain offers generalist funds and public grants (EU programs, CDTI). Game-specific backers are limited; fundraising remains competitive.
Spain's growth steadies, but youth unemployment around 22% and debt above 110% temper the recovery; budget prudence helps families.
Spain's social market economy blends welfare with EU rules; it supports startups through grants and visas, but bureaucracy and labor rigidity may slow growth.
Spain's startup visa and EU policies support founders. Policy shifts around elections are manageable for grants and visas.
Spain's public schools offer solid education with bilingual English programs in major regions. Rural districts may lag and require tutoring.

Spain sponsors non-EU workers but with quotas and paperwork. Startups with niche skills may secure visas, though approvals vary.
Spain hosts a vibrant Unity/Unreal scene (Madrid/Barcelona) with cross-training and indie hubs; variety keeps tooling options open for teams.
Spain offers strong conservation, protected parks, and clean waterways; urban areas have some pollution, while rural and coastal regions stay pleasant.
Spain's progressive IRPF and social security place dual tech incomes in the mid-30s after deductions.
Spain's fall on the coasts stays around 20–25 C; most days are mild with light sweater weather. Brief rain showers are common but quick to clear.
Child-friendly plazas, Sunday family rituals, and multigenerational housing norms create supportive communities, though we still navigate late dining customs for little kids.
Spain allows family reunification for spouses and minor children; with adequate means and housing, all four can qualify with moderate paperwork.
Spain offers universal healthcare, child benefits, and long parental leave; regional disparities and bureaucracy can slow access.
Spain offers universal healthcare and solid family subsidies; benefits are income-based and involve some paperwork.
Spain provides universal healthcare and public schooling after residency registration; cash housing supports often require permanent status.
Spain's casual-chic vibe fits our family. In ES cities, tidy smart-casual works for schools and work, with high-fashion optional.
In Spain, cities like Madrid and Barcelona showcase diverse, body-positive fashion for women; smaller towns remain more traditional.
Spain's Madrid/Barcelona urban fashion blends smart-casual with sneakers; offices vary, finance leans formal, but many roles welcome personal style.
In Spain, autonomy and professional ambition are widely supported; diverse feminine expressions are common with minor conservative pockets.
Spain enforces strict gun licenses and secure storage. Ownership is limited and daily gun exposure is low for families.
In Spain (ES), flirting is generally respectful; venues enforce boundaries and staff intervene, but clear direct communication remains essential.
Spain's Madrid/Barcelona scenes offer a growing founder network with meetups and accelerators; solid mentorship and startup-friendly policies.
Spain has strong fresh markets and diverse dining in Madrid and Barcelona; a few niche cuisines may require travel to other cities.
Spain (ES) locals are consistently warm and helpful when you reach out. With proactive engagement, integration can feel genuine within weeks.

Spain's game dev scene centers on Barcelona and Madrid, with Málaga as an indie hub; openings exist but often require networking.

Spain has strong gender-equality laws with active enforcement (anti-violence, pay parity); leadership is improving but not fully balanced.
Spain's urban centers favor egalitarian gender roles with strong policies. Occasional legacy expectations may linger in workplaces.
In Spain's urban centers, all genders can initiate or decline interest with minimal stigma; some circles retain traditional scripts.
Spain offers healthcare, schooling, and banking access to residents; employment changes and extended travel still require permit updates.
Spain's hotter summers and Mediterranean droughts demand adaptation costs; coastlines offer milder climate, but risks remain for our family.

Spain has universal public healthcare with strong primary and pediatric care; in big cities, non-urgent specialists may have waits of a few months.

Spain's Barcelona/Madrid/Málaga studios hire steadily; most roles fill in 1–2 months, favorable for remote/hybrid teams and first-time visa moves.
Spain (ES), esp. Madrid/Barcelona, startup hiring typically ~2 months; EU funds/Catalonia grants help, though visa steps may slow recruitment.
Spain's mid-sized cities (Valencia, Seville, Zaragoza) offer family flats around €900–€1,300; space is workable with typical rental processes.
Spain's AEAT offers online filing and pre-filled returns. Regional surcharges, wealth tax, and US dual-reporting mean accountants are often needed.
Spain generally welcomes immigrants; English-speaking families usually feel welcome, with occasional migration debates at the national level.
In Spain, white US migrants are largely welcomed and integrated. Some circles question long-term commitment, but expat networks and learning Spanish help.
Public schooling in Spain is free, but quality varies by district. Bilingual programs exist, and informed parents navigate zones to secure good placements.

In Spain, English is common in cities and tech hubs, but schools and government still rely on Spanish; plan to study Spanish.

Spain provides nationwide LGBTQ+ protections and Pride events. Madrid and Barcelona exemplify strong acceptance for LGBTQ+ families.

Spain features visible Marxist influence through Sumar/Podemos in policy; centrists still dominate economics. Open debate exists, though progress is gradual.
In Spain, younger men trend toward caregiving and emotional openness, though older workplaces and families still show residual machismo.
Occasional events occur regionally in Spain (ES). Authorities respond transparently, so stay alert at large gatherings in Madrid, Barcelona, and other cities.
Spain's major cities offer frequent tech, parenting, and language meetups (Madrid/Barcelona); English-friendly events exist, though some groups have fees.
Spain's 2024 SMI is €1,134/mo across 14 payments; for a two-adult family, it covers basics in many regions but housing/childcare remain tight outside metros.
Spain's urban areas offer strong fiber broadband and reliable utilities. Some rural pockets lag, but Madrid/Barcelona provide solid gaming latency.

In Spain, openness is usually welcomed. Share concerns directly, but with tact to respect regional nuances and diverse communities.
Spain's landscapes are dazzling and family-friendly: Pyrenees, Canaries, and Andalusian white villages offer year-round outdoor escapes.
Spain faces occasional wildfires and floods; Canary Islands volcanic alerts are rare but possible. Budget for insurance and simple evacuation plans.

Spain's Madrid and Barcelona host thriving live music and family-friendly festivals with safe transit, ideal for outings with the kids.
Spain has strong urban nightlife, but family-friendly late options are limited; plan early dinners and reliable transit in cities like Madrid or Barcelona.

In Spain's cities, generous lunch breaks and walkable streets create a calmer rhythm that's easier for Sarah's family to balance work and life.
In Spain, schools back collaborative parenting; dads are often involved in school runs, and childcare is well supported.
Spain naturalization generally requires 10 years of residence plus language/civics exams; timelines can be long and approvals uncertain.
Spain's perceived corruption is moderate; municipal/housing scandals persist, but watchdogs and courts pursue accountability.
Spain's social norms are warm and sociable; cheek-kiss greetings and crowded spaces can feel closer, but most cues are read well.
Spain's culture includes cheek-kiss greetings and closer contact; in crowds, read cues—especially with kids.
Spain's Mediterranean climate offers mild springs and falls; summers can be hot inland, but coast towns stay pleasant most of the year.
Spain's constitutional monarchy with proportional representation supports stable coalitions. Reforms advance via open civic channels and plural media.
In Spain, poly networks exist in Barcelona and Madrid, but custody/healthcare remain monogamy-centered; private circles show more tolerance.
In Spain, public 0–3 slots exist but waitlists can be long and co-pays vary. Expect to blend municipal care with private, often bilingual, centers.
Spain has concertado and international private schools with bilingual curricula; tuition about €5–12k and admissions can be competitive.
Spain (ES) has common processed foods. Strong fresh markets balance meals for families, with planning supporting healthy options.
Spain (ES): PMM (Games) comp trails top markets by ~25–30%. Favorable lifestyle and family-friendly policies offset the gap.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Spain offers occasional game marketing upskilling; notable events like Gamelab Barcelona exist, but most learning is remote or self-directed.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Spain has game-dev and marketing programs in Madrid/Barcelona, but dedicated PMM (games) curricula are limited; expect on-the-job upskilling.
Spain's games scene (Madrid/Barcelona) tends to fill PMM roles in 3-4 months; remote options help a family-friendly relocation.
Spain (ES): English is common in game studios. Bilingual Spanish–English PMMs are favored for client-facing work.
Spain studios commonly offer hybrid work for games marketing. Fully remote arrangements are negotiable, with occasional on-site days for collaboration.
Spain (ES) PMM (Games) talent pool: solid with Madrid/Barcelona presence; seniors competitive; relocation or remote options may help.

Spain's Madrid/Barcelona metro and high-speed rail are strong; rural towns still rely on buses or cars for last mile.
Spain has EU funding and dev events in Madrid and Barcelona. Publishers exist but partnerships require proactive outreach.

Spain's real-time game dev scene (Madrid/Barcelona) offers solid pipelines and growing cinematic work; fits Trey/Sarah's needs.

Spain's startups are hybrid-friendly with mature remote tooling and periodic onsite, aligning with the family's remote/hybrid needs.

Spain's family-friendly policies and grants aid retention; funding cycles and visa hurdles may spike churn, especially for startups.
Spain's contributory pension replaces about 70% of wages and universal healthcare aids aging residents. Retirement age is slowly increasing.
Spain's Seguridad Social pension depends on years of work and contributions; visa holders must meet residency rules, so private retirement savings are important.
Ruby roles persist in Spain, mainly Madrid/Barcelona; steady openings with maintenance work, remote options growing but salaries lag top stacks.
Spain is generally safe; crime is low and incidents are well managed, though Barcelona and Madrid tourist cores warrant after-dark caution.

Spain's Mediterranean waters are about 20-26 °C (68-79 °F) May-Oct, great for family swims; shoulder months are cooler with light rash guards.
Spain (ES) generally has mild, manageable seasons. Inland areas can see heatwaves; coastal regions stay comfortable most years.
Spain's long summer days and milder winters help mood stay strong; maintain outdoor time and light-touch coping during the shorter days.
Coastal Spain offers mild winters and hot, dry summers; you will need AC and sun protection, but outdoor time remains feasible.
Spain has an adequate senior tech pool in Madrid/Barcelona; startups must offer competitive packages and clear visa options.
Spain offers comprehensive sex education and open consent discussions; LGBTQ+ inclusive media is common, though pockets of conservatism remain.
Spain's universal healthcare and strong family benefits support your family in ES; regional gaps and admin hurdles prevent a perfect 10.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: 2k sq ft rentals are scarce in Spain's major cities. Expect premium rents or broker help, or consider outer suburbs.
Spring in Spain tends to 15–23 °C (59–73 °F) on the coast; inland areas stay cooler with some windy days; kids may need light jackets.
Stable Spain with resilient institutions; Catalan independence debates and regional tensions trigger occasional protests and snap elections.
Spain's mainstream politics blend social democracy with EU integration and regional identities. It supports pluralism and civil liberties, with open debate.
Spain's dynamic market has EU oversight balancing innovation with protections. It supports startups and universal healthcare, plus bilingual schooling for our family.
7: Healthy number of studios across genres; Madrid/Barcelona hubs anchor indie and mid-size teams, with improving grants and programs.
Coastal Spain summers are 27-32 °C with moderate humidity; rare heatwaves need indoor breaks, fitting the family's mild-climate preference.
In Spain (ES), friendly exchanges typically occur when we initiate. Staff and locals respond positively, especially with English and basic Spanish.
Spain has limited game-specific incentives; funding fluctuates, though general R&D relief exists that games and studios can access.
Spain non-lucrative visa typically 2–6 months. Total costs are a few thousand euros with translations and apostille.
In Spain, trust in national institutions remains modest. Our ES family values transparency and simpler bureaucratic steps.
In Spain, procurement and zoning scandals appear occasionally. Oversight and audits keep permits and large contracts in check, aiding predictable processes for families.
In Spain (Madrid/Barcelona), senior software salaries run €45–65k. Solid locally but below US remote pay.
Weekends in Spain fit our family: late breakfasts, parks/beaches, kids' activities, and tapas with friends; we mix spontaneous outings with a few reservations.
Spain schools commonly 9:00-15:00 with aftercare; 5-year-old in school, 1-year-old in childcare. Manageable with wraparound care and flexible hours.
Spain (ES) guarantees 30 days of paid vacation plus around 14 holidays; strong enforcement and payout for unused days suits family plans.

Spain (ES): English is common in international VFX shops (Madrid/Barcelona), but many studios expect Spanish; the family plans to learn the local language.
Remote options exist case-by-case for real-time VFX in Spain (ES); expect some onsite work in Madrid/Barcelona, aligning with the family's remote-friendly stance.
Spain's real-time VFX pool is solid in Madrid/Barcelona, with outsourcing options; senior hires competitive; relocation or remote hiring may be needed.
Spain's neighbors Portugal and France are cooperative. Regional ties are generally amicable, with occasional Gibraltar or Morocco-related tensions.
Spain blends regional pride with modern, multicultural cities and EU citizenship; generally welcoming to immigrant families.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Spain is seen as welcoming by neighbors, with strong ties to France and Portugal; Catalan debates cause occasional policy frictions.
Spain offers non-lucrative, digital nomad, and entrepreneur visas; expect proof of funds, insurance, and in-person appointments.
Spain's cities offer walkable pockets with parks; expect some car-heavy corridors - plan routes to avoid busy arterials near kids.
Spain's Madrid/Barcelona/Valencia welcome US migrants; locals are curious but English-friendly services help, and learning Spanish eases daily life.
Spain's tapas and fiestas spark curiosity. Barcelona and Madrid's creative tech-art scenes offer ongoing learning beyond Kansas City.
Spain's coastal winters are mild (8–16 °C); inland areas can dip near freezing at night, but snow is rare, keeping heating costs manageable.
Spain's standard 37.5-hour week supports family life. Remote/hybrid options and strong parental leave help families balance work and care in ES.
Spain's work-life balance offers flexible hours and generous vacation, with remote options supporting Sarah and family time.
Spain offers robust worker protections and strong unions. Gig workers still face gaps and enforcement can vary by region.
